doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Employment Cos. Survey SteadyEmployment Cos. Survey Steady_2025-08-29

passages.text: Company Surveys | Employment Cos. Survey
- Following improvement in July, the Evercore ISI Employment Cos. Survey slowed in August, but was unchanged at 50.1 this past week. Overall, the survey remains solid, but in a slowing trend.
- Temp employment ticked down from 53.9 to 53.8, while perm placement was steady at 46.3. Overall wage pressure was unchanged at 52.7.

- Tariffs, government funding and contracts and the macro outlook have weighed on customers' confidence. DOGE's impact has increased in our survey through government contractors and related businesses. Less federal funding is impacting pharma and biotech research hiring and workforce development organizations have seen funding reduced. We also saw an uptick in the impact of immigration policy changes on labor availability.

- After recent delays on tariffs, some participants are reengaging on projects for strategic services, and tech enabled solutions, with the biggest growth areas in financial services and tech software and specialized skill sets. While other cos. are putting positions on hold and not backfilling roles when personnel leave. Clients are very cautious regarding hiring right now and are waiting to see what happens with the next Fed meeting.
Evercore ISI Employment Cos. Survey: Revenues 0=Weak 100=Strong 4 Wk. Avg. Aug 29 50.3

On the direct hire side, clients remain selective, concentrating on core functions. IT hiring is stable, while mfg. hiring has moderated. Concerns about Federal funding has created headwinds. Activity has increased in the consumer goods sector and agriculture.

0=Weak 100=StrongDomestic RevenuesWage Pressure2025Apr50.352.6May50.452.1Jun50.451.8Jul50.951.8Aug 151.251.8Aug 850.752.2Aug 1550.252.3Aug 2250.14 Wk. Avg. 50.5Aug 2950.14 Wk. Avg. 50.352.7 4 Wk. Avg. 52.352.7 4 Wk.Avg. 52.5

The Temp Employment Cos. Survey has accelerated, but companies continue to need IT temps, consultants and F&A related positions. Demand is okay for higher level positions, semi- skilled and customer service type roles, and marketing, while demand for mfg. positions products are flat. Mortgage and collection positions have been mixed, while IT temp positions continue to be stable.
Domestic Revenue SalesWage Pressure2025Apr54.150.9May54.250.6Jun53.650.1Jul54.349.7Aug 155.249.8Aug 854.550.2Aug 1553.550.5Aug 2253.94 Wk. Avg. 54.3Aug 2953.84 Wk. Avg. 53.9

The Perm Placement Cos. Survey shows demand for full time workers has softened more than temp demand which is typical in a slowing economy. Strength is led by IT, F&A, healthcare, front office services, data analysis, sales/business development, engineering, project managers, and quality control. Participants are seeing more candidate responsiveness to job listings and improvement in candidate flow. Clients are focused on developing manufacturing capabilities to deal with supply chain issues. Cloud activity remains robust as does cyber security, and clients have very little discretion around customer facing technology to stay competitive. However, some companies do not appear to be back- filling roles when individuals leave.
DomesticRevenuesWagePressureAprMayJun46.646.647.254.353.553.4Jul47.553.9Aug 147.353.9Aug 8Aug 15Aug 22Aug 2946.846.846.346.34 Wk. Avg.4 Wk. Avg.4 Wk. Avg.4 Wk.Avg.46.846.846.646.654.254.254.254.2
Evercore ISI Permanent Placement Cos. Survey: Domestic Revenues 0=Weak 100=Strong 4 Wk. Avg. Aug 29 46.6
Our survey of companies' expectations for the growth rate on wages over the next 12 mos. is approaching historical average levels, rising from \(+12\%\) to \(+28\%\) . Here is a link.

Labor availability improved over the past month but less broadly. Employment agencies were most likely to report improvement in labor availability as consumer cos. reported deterioration in availability.
% Better minus % Worse

In June we asked our participants in our Employment Survey if DOGE is impacting their business and \(89\%\) are seeing an impact on contractor or govt.- related hiring, up from \(37\%\) when we initially asked, in the first half of March. Some contacts who said no, are concerned over the impact of government funding on biotech, pharma, and local research universities.

The impact in the change in the immigration policy is more modest but rising as \(56\%\) replied in June no impact, down from \(75\%\) when we asked in March, while \(44\%\) felt there was a minimal impact, up from \(25\%\) in March. As a result of new government policies, some companies have elected to discontinue sponsoring of work visas.
No Yes, fewer contractor or govt- related positions/hiring Yes, fewer government positions/hiring
No Yes, minimal impact. Yes, moderate impact.
Do you think companies are "hoarding labor", ie, holding onto workers longer than normal given the challenges with availability in recent years?
Jun'25 No 78% Yes 22%

After falling in 2022, 2023 and much of 2024 amidst moderating employment demand, conversion rates continue to rise in 2025 with the net reading moving up from \(+20\%\) in March to \(+50\%\) in our June check. Conversions of temp workers to full- time workers is a sign of confidence by client firms and suggest solid employment demand. Some clients are hiring the good associates more quickly to permanent employment thus helping to alleviate paying mark ups on higher pay rates.

The Evercore ISI Employment Surveys consist of 13 national and regional temp employment agencies and 13 permanent placement cos. survey in which some, but not all of the companies overlap. The temp employment survey was created in February 1996 and has served as lead indicator of overall U.S. employment trends. The permanent placement survey was created in December 2007 at the suggestion of participants who commented that temp employment typically leads at troughs in the employment cycle while perm placement leads at peaks in the cycle. For each survey, we ask the participants to rate domestic revenues and wage pressure on a \(0 =\) Weak to \(100 =\) Strong scale where \(50 =\) long term trend.

In our mid- year update of our Capex & Hiring Plans Survey, employment plans for 2025 declined on a net basis. This index has only turned negative around U.S. recessions, and the reading of \(- 7\%\) is a notable change from December's \(+22\%\) as companies have turned more cautious. Here is the link to the full report.
Evercore ISI Company Survey Of U.S. Employment Plans
Industrial Cos. Employment Cos.
Real Estate Cos. Transport Cos.

Labor availability is improving around the world, and our corporate survey shows the U.S. as the only region where labor remains hard to get. However, availability of labor in the U.S. has improved materially since Nov. '21 when we started asking this question.
- 100 = Very Hard To Get 100= Very Easy To Get

In our update on corporate investment in generative A.I., 46% of contacts report that generative AI is already augmenting human labor in a material way, up from 34% one year ago and 14% in our Summer 2023 check. A few respondents, all employment cos., tell us they have already started to replace human labor with generative AI up from none in our check 24 months ago, while 67% of companies across all industries report that replacement is more than a year away, and 24% of organizations, up from 18% last May, tell us replacement will never happen. Here is the link to the full report.
When Do You Expect To Start Using Generative AI In A Material Way To Augment Human Labor?
When Do You Expect To Start Using Generative AI In A Material Way To Replace Human Labor?
